title: A feast of new Vaughan Williams records remind us why he’s Britain’s favourite composer
text:
On Albion’s Journey, one of three superb recent releases by Albion Records, there is a marvellous and regrettably short recording of Ralph Vaughan Williams talking about folk music, and the importance of a national idiom in music. He points out that other great composers from Europe were “national” in their outlook – he cites Bach, no less, in evidence.

When Vaughan Williams was speaking (there is no date given, but it sounds as though it comes from the Forties or early Fifties), his own music was going out of fashion, and it remained largely so for a quarter-century after his death in 1958 – despite the championship of conductors like Boult and Barbirolli, and André Previn’s ground-breaking...
